name: noname
text: In this video i'm going to describe how the text to speech addon works

name: noname
text: Firstly, we need to install the addon

name: noname
text: If you're using Windows, you will need to right click blender and click run as administrator, just this one time

name: noname
text: We can install the addon by opening the preferences in Blender, and installing the Text to Speech zip file

name: noname
text: It might take a moment to install the google text to speech library

name: noname
text: When you navigate to the video editing interface you should see the Text to Speech tab

name: noname
text: If it doesn't appear, you can toggle the system console to see any errors in Windows

name: noname
text: In linux you can open blender from a terminal to see the output

name: noname
text: Let me know if you have any issues

name: noname
text: You can make individual audio strips by typing something in the text field and pressing speechify

name: noname
text: Alternatively you can import a closed caption file and it will convert all the strips to audio

name: noname
text: Accent can be chosen before speechify or file import

name: noname
text: Currently only text files, s.r.t and s.b.v files are supported

name: noname
text: If time codes are provided, audio strips will be placed at that time

name: noname
text: In the case of txt files, audio strips will be placed one after another

name: noname
text: After importing, you can move the audio strips around, delete them, and mix with individual audio strips

name: noname
text: You can then export closed caption files and it will export an updated file that corresponds to your current audio strips

name: noname
text: You can save blender, reopen and it will remember the text associated with the audio strips for further editing

name: noname
text: Thanks for watching

name: noname
text: Let me know if you have any issues!
